sentence: Wall Street was bouncing back from Thursday's sell-off, supported by bargain-hunting among healthcare and technology stocks.

A miss on a pair of key manufacturing indices as well as another drop in construction spending during March barely made a dent in today's upward bias although the rally stalled below yesterday's high-water mark.

Dow components Apple ( AAPL ) and Home Depot ( HD ) were leading blue-chips higher while a solid gain for drugmaker Gilead Sciences ( GILD ) was helping lift the S&P 500 above its 50-day moving average of 2,091.
Investors had plenty of economic data to chew on today although the numbers largely failed to generate much of a contrary response.
The final read for the purchasing managers index edged lower to 54.1 in April from a 55.7 final reading in March, also trailing market estimates looking for a dip to 54.5.
Also, the Institute for Supply Management manufacturing index was unchanged at 51.5, trailing expectations for a small rise to a 52.0 reading.
Construction spending contracted 0.6% during March for its third decline over the past four months, also tracking well under the Street view looking for a 0.4% rise.
But the one bright spot among today's data was a rise in consumer sentiment, with the Thompson Reuters/University of Michigan index climbing to a final 95.9 April reading from 93.0 in March.
Wall Street, however, was expecting an increase to 96.0.
Most of Europe, with the exception of the UK, was closed Friday for the Labor Day holiday.
The FTSE eked out a modest gain following a rally for Lloyds Banking Group ( LYG ) after it reported better-than-expected quarterly results.
But gains were mitigated ahead of UK parliamentary elections next week as well as sluggish manufacturing data for April.
Crude oil was down 84 cents to $58.79 per barrel.
Natural gas was up $16 cents to $2.78 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was down $10.90 to $1,171.40 an ounce, while silver was down 70 cents to $16.04 an ounce and copper rose 3 cents to $2.92 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was down 1.46% with the United States Natural Gas Fund was up 2.01% to $13.72.
Amongst precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was down 0.68% to 21.56 while SPDR Gold Shares were down 0.88% to $112.47.
The iShares Silver Trust was down 0.84% to $15.31.

Here's where the U.S. markets stood at mid-day:

(+) ENOC (+23.53%) Missed Q1 revenue and issued weak EPS forecast.
Credit Suisse downgraded to neutral from outperform, and cut PT $10.
(+) ZEUS (+23.39%) Reported Q1 profit of $0.10 vs estimates for $0.40 loss, beat revenue expectations.
(-) CTRL (-18.94%) Reported weak Q1 results, downgraded at Canaccord to hold from buy.
